key_title: Key to the species of Stylidium

Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Stylidiaceae

source.author: Raulings, E.J.
source.title: Stylidiaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Raulings, E.J. (1999). Stylidiaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Plants ephemeral, 1–30 cm high; leaves fewer than 10
Plants perennial, 5–150 cm high; leaves more than 10
Calyx-tube globular, shorter than the lobes; calyx-lobes free; stigma strap- or fan-shaped with an apical brush or hairs; corolla-lobes folded at night or in dull weather
Calyx-tube linear, longer than the lobes; 2 calyx-lobes united almost to their tips; stigma cushion-like, hairy all over; corolla-lobes remaining spread until senescence
Corolla 6–15 mm across, white or pink; stigma strap-like and fringed, projecting beyond the anthers
Corolla less than 5 mm across, white; stigma fan-shaped and brush-tipped
Nectary spur of corolla as long or longer than subtending calyx-lobe
Nectary spur of corolla absent or shorter than subtending calyx-lobe
Corolla 3–4 mm across, never fan-shaped, the lobes oriented in opposing pairs, white or pale pink without external stripes; throat appendages fewer than 6
Corolla 1.5–3.0 mm across, c. fan-shaped, pale pink with a deep rose stripe along outer side of each lobe, posterior lobes twice as long as anterior lobes; throat appendages 6
Leaves in basal rosettes or tufts
Leaves not rosetted, crowded along the branches; far East Gippsland only
Leaves linear-lanceolate, never incurved, hair at leaf-tip absent; flowers in erect racemes; throat appendages 6–8
Leaves narrowly oblanceolate, incurved and closely packed, forming a basin, each often tipped by a long hair; flowers in a loose corymb or corymbose panicle; throat appendages absent; Grampians only
Leaf width less than 3 mm, more or less linear
Leaf width at least 3 mm or, if  less than 3 mm, then leaf narrowly oblanceolate to oblanceolate
Flowers white to pale pink; plants generally not or only weakly rhizomatous; mainly sandy or clay soils from near sea-level to c. 500 m a.s.l.
Flowers deep pink to magenta; plants typically strongly rhizomatous and forming compact clumps; restricted to peaty soils of montane to sub-alpine areas
Longest leaf (2–)5–40 cm, if longest leaf not greater than 11 cm then pilose; plants solitary or rhizomatous with 2–5 tufts; widespread from the coast to the subalps
Longest leaf 2–12 cm, glabrous; plants typically strongly rhizomatous and forming compact clumps of up to c. 50 tufts; restricted to moist, peaty soils of sub-alpine and alpine areas
